title: Put more female barristers on television to redress gender imbalance, lawyers insist
text:
Make more television shows with female barristers, lawyers have insisted, as new figures show less than a quarter of those in the profession are women.

Just 23.6 per cent of 7,409 barristers currently working in the UK are female, compared with 17.3 per cent in 2010, according to think tank Chambers and Partners.

Painfully slow progress in remedying the gender imbalance in the last decade has prompted calls for more to be done to attract women into the profession and incentivise them to stick with it long enough to progress to the most senior positions.

One idea is that more women should be enticed into the profession by seeing female barristers in action on influential television programmes.

Claire Darwin, of Matrix Chambers, told The Telegraph: "Growing up, long before I met any real barristers, I was a huge fan of This Life, the BBC 2 drama about young barristers.

"I think Anna, the barrister with a colourful personal life, is my all-time favourite fictional barrister. She was gutsy and brilliant. We need more Annas at the Bar, and fewer Miles types!"

Ms Darwin said TV dramas give insight into what life at the Bar is really like.

She added: "After Silk aired on TV, friends of mine from school told me that they better understood what my job involved."

Punishing working hours and unpredictable schedules being incompatible with childcare is among the reasons talented women are dropping out mid-career.

The Bar Council, which represents barristers in England and Wales, has previously highlighted the problem of retention, pointing out that only 15 per cent of the most senior barristers, known as QCs, are women.
description: Make more television shows with female barristers, lawyers have insisted, as new figures show less than a quarter of those in the profession are women.
